body: Glad to have you on board :)

Airflow is a batch processing workflow engine, so minimizing the overhead around scheduling each task isn't a huge priority. We are committed in making it easy to keep the overhead of each task under a minute or so.

Knowing this, if you run a lot of sub-minute tasks, overhead becomes an important percentage of your overall timeline. Also note that the platform might become "metadata-heavy". If you were to use Airflow to run millions of sub-second task, the overhead would considerably outweigh the actual work.

Stream processing solutions are much better suited for many use cases. Check out Spark Streaming,  Samza, Storm or Heron to see whether they better satisfy your use case.

What about using environment variables instead?
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/installation.html#configuration

Dynamically generating commands based on keys in a config file and running them to catch their stdout seem like a not so great idea...

Also python in general and the whole airflow codebase uses PEP8 as a style guideline. No camelCase vars and function names please.

Even with env variables, `my_conn_string` will contain the password in plain text. 
I am looking to avoid storing the password in plain text anywhere on the machine.

Happy to change to change it to PEP8 style.
I'm not sure how `./foo` outputting a password is better than having `cat foo` output one?

@criccomini yes, you can view the STDOUT via airflow web-ui. (just try it :-) ).

I'm providing an example of how we use this callback at Agari. We have an hourly DAG that scores some data. It needs to complete within 2 hours (i.e. within our configured SLA for run completion), otherwise, we need to page the on-call engineer and post a message in our ops slack channel as part of our slack ops initiative.

In the example below, we specify a callback called `sla_alert_func`. That function, defined in another file, executes a VictorOps API call to page our on-call and then posts some info in our ops slack channel,

```
default_args = {
    'owner': 'sanand',
    'depends_on_past': False,
    'pool': 'ep_data_pipeline',
    'start_date': START_DATE,
    'email': [import_ep_pipeline_alert_email_dl],
    'email_on_failure': import_airflow_enable_notifications,
    'email_on_retry': import_airflow_enable_notifications,
    'retries': 1,
    'retry_delay': timedelta(seconds=120),
    'priority_weight': import_airflow_priority_weight
}
dag = DAG(DAG_NAME, schedule_interval='@hourly', default_args=default_args, sla_miss_callback=sla_alert_func)

# FUNCTIONS
def sla_alert_func(dag, task_list, blocking_task_list, slas, blocking_tis):
    logger.info('Executing SLA miss callback')

    message_type = 'info'
    if ENV == 'EP_PROD':
        message_type = 'critical'

    # Execute VictorOps alerting
    message_name = "{env} - {dag_name} SLA Miss for task `{task_list}`".format(**{
        'dag_name': dag.dag_id,
        'task_list': task_list,
        'env': ENV,
    })

    userdata ={"message_type": message_type,
               "state_message": message_name,
               "monitoring_tool": "airflow",
               "entity_id":"airflow/telemetry/SLA_miss"}
    requests.post('https://alert.victorops.com/integrations/generic/0000000/alert/{}/ep'.format(victorops_key), data=json.dumps(userdata))

    # Execute Slack alerting
    report_issues_on_slack_util(message_name)
```

FYI, you can create a DAG that is not scheduled : `schedule_interval=None` 

You can then use an Sensor to detect new data - e.g. S3 Sensor to detect new data S3 and have it trigger your DAG to run!

@mistercrunch quite some work has gone into this any objections?

Thanks @syvineckruyk Currently, SLA miss checks are done in the scheduler. Each worker or executor will execute an operator. The central scheduler (or perhaps another daemon in the future) queries the DB to figure out which tasks are falling behind and sends a report of all tasks that have missed their SLAs in a single email. In that centralized logic, I added the callback hook to allow for similar notifications : I currently publish the list of delayed tasks to both VictorOps and Slack. Here's a screen capture of the Slack Notification for one execution of a callback -- 2 tasks were behind. Though each task defines its SLAs, the detection and reporting of the SLA misses happens in the scheduler in jobs.py.

+1 This is something we need as well. We have all sorts of 3rd party API integrations that require some sort of key management solution (VictorOps/PagerDuty, Loggly/SumoLogic/LogEntries/DataDog/, Slack, etc...). For people that use AWS, there can be some integration with KMS (Key Management System/Store?) or some other option. This is a good feature request.

The argument could be made that all 3rd party integrations be developed via hooks that use connections and leveraged via operators (if I understand the relationship between those concepts correctly), but it's better to offer the encrypted variable route as well as that makes it easier for people using the general-purpose PythonOperator to make API calls out to 3rd parties.

This seems interesting. I'm sure we will have some encrypted-variable use cases, but the encryption use case that I have is slightly different. If we run code inside a Docker (https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/882) container, which needs some certs to access things, we have no easy way of getting them there. The difference here is that 1) We already have a secret store already (https://github.com/hashicorp/vault) and 2) I am interested in files, not strings.

I have the same problem with zombies in supervisor.  The only issue with PR-#855 is that the fix to this issue would only work for systemd users I believe.  It might be more of a universal solution to use an os.exec\* variant instead of Popen as suggested above, or to utilize a signal handler to relay signals to the gunicorn child.  Then the PR-#855, which daemonizes airflow webserver by default, could be handled as a separate issue.

I agree that this PR makes airflow match common webservers that daemonize by default.  However, it's worth noting that other commands such as 'airflow scheduler' and 'airflow flower' don't behave this way.  I think it makes sense to handle all the sub-processes the same way, whichever way it goes.  And in all cases, a switch to do the opposite ( keep in foreground or daemonize) would be good.
@mistercrunch  What is the `extra` field for? Is it a notes section?

The switch is already in place. Im working on the other daemons.

The `extra` field is used for json blobs for anything connection related that doesn't really fit into the classic host/login/psw classic pattern. Say a specific API might have a key or some account id. The HiveOperator supports a beeline=True extra param, ... You can grep for extra under hooks and see how it's been used so far.

I think we should use `.get` everywhere and have a set of conf elements as a class level attribute that defines the elements that can be fetched as a command.

in the `ConfigParserWithDefaults` class, add something like:

```
# These configuration elements can be fetched as the stdout of commands
# following the "{section}__{name}__cmd" pattern, the idea behind this is to not
# store password on boxes in text files, ....
as_command_stdout = {
    ('core', 'sql_alchemy_conn'),
    ('celery', 'broker_...'),
    ...
}
```

Then apply the precedence rule in `ConfigParserWithDefaults.get`. Probably document the precedence rule in the docstring as well.

We currently have a functioning SqoopOperator that we use internally. Currently the feature set is based on our need and may be considered rather limited. I would be interested to hear what the community is looking in terms of features from a SqoopOperator.

Currently our Sqoop Operator has the benefit of using the connections from Airflow ... so no need to to have your connection strings and credentials in your code or command parameter. It takes tool (import,export etc...), args, kwargs and templated option file as parameters.

I'm not sure if I'm missing something here. 

When the task instance is UP_FOR_RETRY, the end_date marks the time of the failure. The line of code you are trying to alter is the one that just makes sure that the retry_delay is done expired, and that the next try can start. I don't see how it is necessary. If you put a short retry_delay, tasks will always be retried, unless somehow end_date is set far in the future, which I don't see how it would ever happen.
Cool. I thought we wanted to make the fallback a general rule of thumb. Updated to support only the 3 elements we need.
I think we have something solid now. Thanks for your contribution!

I think I found a solution to daemonize airflow's webserver and scheduler under CentOS. I tried using the scripts provided in scripts/systemd, but I couldn't get the webserver and scheduler to work on the same box for some reason. The child processes for gunicorn weren't dying consistently either. I am using a configuration similar to those above but CentOS doesn't have the start-stop-daemon calls. I am not a bash expert or anything so feel free to make it better.

I tried to make the solution generic so it's broken up into 3 files that live under /etc/init.d

/etc/init.d/daemonize

``` bash
. /etc/rc.d/init.d/functions

if [ -z ${NAME+x} ]; then
  echo "NAME is not set"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ -z ${APPDIR+x} ]; then
  echo "APPDIR is not set"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ -z ${OWNER+x} ]; then
  echo "OWNER is not set"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ -z ${PIDDIR+x} ]; then
  echo "PIDDIR is not set"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ -z ${PIDFILE+x} ]; then
  echo "PIDFILE is not set"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ -z ${BASECMD+x} ]; then
  echo "BASECMD is not set"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ -z ${CMD+x} ]; then
  echo "CMD is not set"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ ! -d ${APPDIR} ]; then
  echo "${APPDIR} does not exist"
  exit 1001
fi

if [ ! -d "${APPDIR}/logs" ]; then
  (mkdir ${APPDIR}/logs && chown ${OWNER}:${OWNER} ${APPDIR}/logs)
fi

if [ ! -d "${PIDDIR}" ]; then
  mkdir -p ${PIDDIR}
fi

daemonize() {
  case "$1" in
    start)
      start
      ;;
    stop)
      stop
      ;;
    reload|restart)
      $0 stop
      $0 start
      ;;
    status)
      status -p ${PIDFILE} ${NAME}
      exit $?
      ;;
    *)
      echo "Usage: `basename $0` start|stop|status|restart|reload"
      exit 1
  esac
}

make_pid_file() {
  pid=`ps -ef | grep -v grep | grep "${BASECMD}" | tr -s ' ' | cut -d' ' -f2`
  if [ -n "$pid" ]; then
    echo "$pid" > "$PIDFILE"
  fi
}

start() {
  echo -n "Starting $NAME"
  daemon --user="${OWNER}" --pidfile="${PIDFILE}" "${CMD}" || return 2
  make_pid_file
  echo
  return 0
}

stop() {
  echo -n "Stopping $NAME"
  pid=`cat ${PIDFILE}`
  if [ "${USEPKILL}" = true ]; then
    pkill -INT -P ${pid}
  else
    kill -INT ${pid}
  fi
  RETVAL="$?"
  echo
  [ "$RETVAL" = 2 ] && return 2
  rm -f "$PIDFILE"
  return "$RETVAL"
}
```

/etc/init.d/airflow-webserver

``` bash
#!/bin/bash

OWNER=hdfs
APPDIR=/var/lib/hdfs/airflow
NAME=airflow-webserver
PIDDIR="/var/run/airflow"
PIDFILE="${PIDDIR}/webserver.pid"
LOGFILE="${APPDIR}/logs/airflow.log"
BASECMD="airflow webserver"
CMD="${BASECMD} > ${LOGFILE} 2>&1 &"
USEPKILL=true

. /etc/rc.d/init.d/daemonize
daemonize "$@"
exit 0
```

/etc/init.d/airflow-scheduler

``` bash
#!/bin/bash

OWNER=hdfs
APPDIR=/var/lib/hdfs/airflow
NAME=airflow-scheduler
PIDDIR="/var/run/airflow"
PIDFILE="${PIDDIR}/scheduler.pid"
LOGFILE="${APPDIR}/logs/airflow-scheduler.log"
SCHEDULER_RUNS=5
BASECMD="airflow scheduler"
CMD="${BASECMD} -n ${SCHEDULER_RUNS} > ${LOGFILE} 2>&1 &"
USEPKILL=false

. /etc/rc.d/init.d/daemonize
daemonize "$@"
exit 0
```
@bolkedebruin btw, without this patch, LDAP on master won't work unless dataprofiler/superuser filters are set (i.e. master is broken for default use case right now).

PR updated.

Now if login is set into the connection, it is used as proxy user.

I preferred to have also a way to override it in the constructor, since it can be useful in certain situations, where you have to deal with different proxy users and defining an hdfs connection for each one can be "too static".
